priorVersion.title: CDISC SDTM Subject Characteristic Test Code Terminology

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C74559

self.title: CDISC SDTM Subject Characteristic Test Code Terminology

definition: The test code representing each subject characteristic.
name: Subject Characteristic Test Code
preferredTerm: CDISC SDTM Subject Characteristic Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: The number of brothers that are biologically related to the subject. (NCI)
The number of sisters that are biologically related to the subject. (NCI)
An indication as to whether the subject was breast fed (received mother's milk) as an infant.

A public health activity whereby individuals who have been exposed to a person with a suspected or confirmed contagious illness are identified, usually for the purpose of identifying additional cases of the illness, or to offer some form of prophylactic intervention to either prevent or ameliorate disease in the exposed individual.
The date on which the subject arrived in the reporting country from the country of potential disease exposure.
terms.preferredTerm: Entry Date from Country of Potential Disease Exposure
synonyms: Entry Date from Ptntl Cntry Disease Exp

terms.definition: System of classification based on the nation in which an individual was exposed to a disease, regardless of the nation in which he/she currently resides.
The conditions under which an organ is harvested from a dead donor, including the condition of the donor and the environment.
The donor's state or condition of being either living or brain dead at the time of organ harvesting.
terms.preferredTerm: Donor Status at Time of Organ Donation
synonyms: Donor Status at Time of Organ Donation

terms.definition: Highest level of education that a person has attained.
The number of years of education that a person has completed.
A code specifying the job performed by the employee for the employer. For example, accountant, programmer analyst, patient care associate, staff nurse, etc.
The gestational age of the subject at birth.
The preferred hand of use for controlled and efficient performance of motor tasks.

An indication as to whether an organ donor may fall into one or more behavioral categories associated with increased risk of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, as defined by the 1994 Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Public Health Service Criteria for High Risk Behavior (Guidelines for preventing transmission of human immunodeficiency virus through transplantation of human tissue and organs. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. MMWR Recomm Rep 1994; 43: 1-17).
terms.preferredTerm: CDC HIV High Risk Donor Indicator
synonyms: CDC HIV High Risk Donor Indicator

terms.definition: An indication of the position on a scale measuring revenue or monetary support.
A code qualifying the employment in various ways, such as, full-time vs. part time, etc.
The main language that is spoken by the subject most frequently or dominantly.
Additional language(s) that is spoken by the subject but not considered the primary language.
An indication as to whether the associated person is living with the subject. (NCI)
A demographic parameter indicating a person's current conjugal status.
System of classification based on nation from which a person originates, regardless of the nation in which he/she currently resides.
An indication as to whether the subject was born prior to 38 weeks gestation.
The categorization of individuals with or without the potential for having a particular disease.
An indication that a subject is part of a population group that has a greater chance of contracting a disease or disorder.
Social factors such as personal behavior, lifestyle, or environment belonging to the subject which are known to increase the likelihood of infection and disease.
A code specifying the method used by the employer to compute the employee's salary or wages. For example, hourly, annual, or commission.
The environment within which the person may have come into contact with a disease carrier, or played the role of a disease carrier.
The physical sexual characteristics of the neonate at birth.
Test to categorize the sensitivity of a subject's skin to sunlight. (Fitzpatrick TB. The validity and practicality of sun-reactive skin types I through VI. Arch. Dermatol. 1998 124: 869-871.)
A distinctive characteristic of the skin marked by the amount of sebum secreted by sebaceous glands.
An indication as to whether the fetus or infant is small for the gestational age.

A public health activity for the determination of who transmitted a disease to another subject and whether this person: is still infectious; was reported to the health department as a disease case or suspect; or has infected others.
An indication as to whether the subject or associated person is enrolled in school.
Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.
The classification of the two offspring born from the same pregnancy.
Identification and clinical investigation of disease contacts.
